questions.question_text:
A government organization operates and maintains several ICS environments. The categorization of one of the ICS environments led to a moderate baseline. The organization has complied a set of applicable security controls based on this categorization.
Given that this is a unique environment, which of the following should the organization do NEXT to determine if other security controls should be considered?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A. Check for any relevant or required overlays.

Overlay - "A specification of security controls, control enhancements, supplemental guidance, and other supporting information employed during the tailoring process, that is intended to complement (and further refine) security control baselines. The overlay specification may be more stringent or less stringent than the original security control baseline specification and can be applied to multiple information systems."

A.
https://www.cdse.edu/documents/student-guides/CS103-guide.pdf

A.
I think the key is that this is a UNIQUE environment, so all you can really do is check for overlays.

Maybe: A. Check for any relevant or required overlays?
The two environments have similarities, but are not identical. To find which controls for one system might be relevant to another you check for overlays
A- Check for any relevant or required overlays
B. Review enhancements within the current control set

choices.C: Modify to a high-baseline set of controls.
choices.B: Review enhancements within the current control set.
choices.A: Check for any relevant or required overlays.

questions.question_text:
A security researcher is gathering information about a recent spoke in the number of targeted attacks against multinational banks. The spike is on top of already sustained attacks against the banks. Some of the previous attacks have resulted in the loss of sensitive data, but as of yet the attackers have not successfully stolen any funds.
Based on the information available to the researcher, which of the following is the MOST likely threat profile?

choices.B: Insiders seeking to gain access to funds for illicit purposes.
choices.A: Nation-state-sponsored attackers conducting espionage for strategic gain.
choices.C: Opportunists seeking notoriety and fame for personal gain.
choices.D: Hacktivists rolling out a marketing campaign to change landing pages.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is correct

Selected Answer: A
Going with A. Nation-state-sponsored attackers conducting espionage for strategic gain.

Selected Answer: D
I have no reason to think it's an insider. I don't see it being for fame or simply opportunists. Nation state sponsored attackers want information about governments, not multi nation banks. As dumb as it sounds, I'd have to go with D because hacktivists can be politically or socially motivated. They haven't stolen funds but they have stolen sensitive data, which hacktivists can use for political gain or as a means of exposing someone or something as a means to support their idea of accountability.
Just my two cents.
I believe "A" is correct, base on the description
I believe D. is the correct answer because the banks are "multi-national".
Going with A on this one

choices.A: Set up a VDI environment that prevents copying and pasting to the local workstations of outsourced staff members
choices.B: Install a client-side VPN on the staff laptops and limit access to the development network
choices.D: Use remote SaaS to provide administrative sharing in production
choices.C: Create an IPSec VPN tunnel from the development network to the office of the outsourced staff

discussion.content: Concur with B

comments.content: preventing copy paste will slow down the development, whereas VPN implementation can be accompanied by DLP too

questions.question_text: A security engineer is designing a system in which offshore, outsourced staff can push code from the development environment to the production environment securely. The security engineer is concerned with data loss, while the business does not want to slow down its development process. Which of the following solutions BEST balances security requirements with business need?

An organization is considering the use of a thin client architecture as it moves to a cloud-hosted environment. A security analyst is asked to provide thoughts on the security advantages of using thin clients and virtual workstations.
Which of the following are security advantages of the use of this combination of thin clients and virtual workstations?

discussion.content: Answer B appears to address both the physical thin client's AND the virtual workstation's individual benefits (questions asks for plural advantages)... also, answer D assumes to much about data extraction, which could be performed by a user via a private, third party cloud based storage.

Answer B seems to be true, but answer D also seems to be true.
D. Malicious users will have reduced opportunities for data extractions from their physical thin client workstations, this reducing the effectiveness of local attacks.

choices.B: Thin client workstations require much less security because they lack storage and peripherals that can be easily compromised, and the virtual workstations are protected in the cloud where security is outsourced.
choices.A: Malicious insiders will not have the opportunity to tamper with data at rest and affect the integrity of the system.
choices.C: All thin clients use TPM for core protection, and virtual workstations use vTPM for core protection with both equally ensuring a greater security advantage for a cloud-hosted environment.
choices.D: Malicious users will have reduced opportunities for data extractions from their physical thin client workstations, this reducing the effectiveness of local attacks.

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is attempting to break into a client's secure network. The analyst was not given prior information about the client, except for a block of public IP addresses that are currently in use.
After network enumeration, the analyst's NEXT step is to perform:

discussion.content: you guys need to understand the steps in a penetration test methodology. After enumeration, you check for vulnerabilities. answer is C

Selected Answer: C
The question asks what is the Analysts next step, not what type of test this is. Vulnerability assessment is the next step.

Selected Answer: A
I agree with A because with Black box you aren't given anything except maybe the company's name. Grey box is when limited info is given. As limited as the info is, it's still given. Also, I would be more inclined to pick C if it said vulnerability scan, but it doesn't, it says assessment...

He's attempting to break in, and he's enumerated their network, so now he's going to make a vulnerability assessment. It makes sense. You don't change a box assessment in the middle, you go into it knowing what type you're doing, not changing it halfway.

Maybe: C. a vulnerability assessment ?
A black box assessment does not turn into a grey box assessment when progress is made. After enumeration, the next step is finding vulnerabilities.
A is correct

In my mind A is the only real answer it could be. He was given some information, but then has had to get the rest on his own. "gray-box tester has already been granted some internal knowledge that may come in the form of lower-level credentials, application logic flow charts, or network infrastructure maps. "

comments.content:
The color of the box is determined by what they are given from the start. They were not given any info except publicly available IPs, that's black box. It doesn't then become a gray box after figuring things out. Much the same way if you totally own a network, your test doesn't suddenly become a White Box test. 

You're going to enumerate hosts and services and then move on to a vulnerability assessment.

discussion.content: Why not E?

comments.content: Because he is Breaking into a clients network. Red team would be a security analyst attempting to break into his own organizations network.

Then why not C? Grey-box pen testing is a classification of pen testing, not a discrete step in the testing process. I believe this is a grey-box test (he's been given SOME info about the network), but the next step after a network scan isn't a grey-box test, the network scan is part of the grey-box test. Probably a vulnerability assessment comes next.
